title: Is Celine Phantom The Next Big Designer Comeback Bag?
description: The 2010s were the golden age of the It bag ‚Äî and few designers had a hold over the category quite like Phoebe Philo.¬† The British designer became Celine‚Äôs creative director in 2008, and had her first hit in the accessories department shortly thereafter, with the introduction of the Luggage bag in 2009. The boxy tote, with its distinctive handle placements and exterior zipper, quickly became a staple on the arms of the oft-papped, from Nicole Richie to Lindsay Lohan to Rihanna.¬† ‚ÄúThat was the height of the It bag era and the It Girl era,‚Äù says Noelle Sciacca, associate director of fashion and strategic partnerships at The RealReal. ‚ÄúWhether you were in the fashion space or not, you knew what that bag was because of the paparazzi photos‚Ä¶ If you saw Lindsay Lohan or someone from The Simple Life had it, you wanted that style.‚Äù As a result, this ignited a desire for boxier handbags, even among shoppers who didn‚Äôt have a Celine budget. (Most Luggage bags fell in the $2,000-$3,500 range.) ‚ÄúEvery contemporary brand, every mall brand started to do that [Luggage] shape because it felt so unique,‚Äù she says.¬† A few years later, in 2011, Philo riffed on the design and birthed another soon-to-become icon: the Phantom. Roomier than the Luggage, with wings jutting out from either side, the Phantom was inspired by Celine suitcases from the 1970s. It boasted the same handles and zipper (except the latter had a long braided rope pull) as its handbag sibling, so, together, they were often referred to as the ‚Äúsmile bags.‚Äù The silhouette attracted an even bigger celebrity following than the Luggage, spotted on the arms of Kim Kardashian, Gwyneth Paltrow, and Celine Dion, as well as models of the moment like Alessandra Ambrosio and Lily Aldridge. ‚ÄúThe Phantom always stood out because of its oversized, unstructured shape and dramatic wings,‚Äù says Anais Rivera, director of procurement at Fashionphile. ‚ÄúIt felt bolder, cooler, and a little less polished than the rest. It has this effortless, slouchy vibe that makes it feel different. It doesn‚Äôt try too hard, and that‚Äôs exactly what made people gravitate toward it. You could throw it over your shoulder with jeans and a tee, and still look elevated.‚Äù¬† Almost 15 years later, there‚Äôs a lot of nostalgia around the Phantom, especially for millennials who wanted one during its heyday but couldn‚Äôt afford it. ‚ÄúI remember being in college and dreaming of owning one ‚Äî I would‚Äôve given you my left kidney to buy one,‚Äù says Rivera. ‚ÄúThat bag defined a whole era.‚Äù Sciacca was an assistant at a fashion magazine at the time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs similar to what the Miu Miu Sparkle Bootie was for me ‚Äî one of those iconic accessories that everyone wanted to call in, that was seen on every cool editor,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI would try it on and play with it when it was in the fashion closet. It definitely has a hold on me personally.‚Äù To Sophie Hersan, the co-founder and fashion director of Vestiaire Collective, the Phantom is inextricably linked to Philo, embodying ‚Äúthe ghost of Phoebe,‚Äù who left Celine in 2017.¬†‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the day-to-day bag for modern women,‚Äù she says, likening it to a Herm√®s Birkin in its utility. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs for the modern woman who works and has a messy bag. Not everyone can afford a Birkin, but the Phantom is exactly what every woman wants‚Ä¶ I was waiting for the maison [to reissue] it.‚Äù Michael Rider, Celine‚Äôs new designer, worked at the brand when both the Luggage and Phantom came out. Though he was on the ready-to-wear team at the time, he dipped into the accessories of the era for his debut as creative director for Spring 2026 and reintroduced the Phantom ‚Äî bigger, but slightly shorter, and even wider ‚Äî in black, brown, and Yves Klein blue (another nod to Philo). Rider even riffed on the bag‚Äôs unofficial nickname, curving the zipper upwards so it resembled a smile.¬† ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs this nice, beautiful way to honor the codes of the fashion house, but also add this playful irreverence to it, and indicate the direction in which he‚Äôs going to take it,‚Äù Sciacca says.¬† Even before Rider‚Äôs runway debut in July, the Celine Phantom had been on the minds of resale shoppers. Fashionphile reported that it saw the highest search volume for the style of the year back in January, with a 79% increase from the prior month. In the days after the show in Paris, though, searches were up 1,205%, compared to the preceding week.¬† On The RealReal, searches for the Celine Phantom were up 120% on the day of the Celine show, and nearly doubled the next day. Obsessions ‚Äî when users ‚Äúheart‚Äù an item on the resale platform ‚Äî are up 123% year-on-year; searches are up 263% year-on-year. ‚ÄúWhat world news is for the stock market, fashion news is for the resale market,‚Äù says Sciacca. ‚ÄúWe always see that correlation: As a past season It bag gets reintroduced on the runway, it automatically creates a desire. People have to wait months for Spring 2026 to go into production and be released by the brand. People see it and they want it, so that instantly drives them to the resale market.‚Äù Hersan has noticed secondhand‚Äôs impact on the firsthand market at Vestiaire Collective, too ‚Äî when ‚Äúthere‚Äôs such a demand [for] a bag, an accessory, or ready-to-wear that you can find it again in the new collection from the maison.‚Äù (The platform saw a 10x increase in searches for the Phantom after the Celine show in July, compared to June.) She first picked up on it when Dior reissued the Saddle, and foresaw it happening with the Chlo√© Paddington (also designed by Philo, who was the creative director of the brand from 2001 to 2006) once Chemena Kamali joined the brand. She sees this as an effort from brands to own their heritage and show customers that they can stick with a brand even amid designer switch-ups. ‚ÄúAll the codes are there,‚Äù she says.¬† Sciacca points to nostalgia as another driving factor: ‚ÄúThe people who loved the bag [when it first came out] and feel nostalgic for it want to gravitate towards it again, but then that new generation is able to adopt it for the first time. It‚Äôs a good time for brands to play on that.‚Äù¬† Beyond that, the Phantom comeback is aligned with a desire we‚Äôre seeing for big bags, specifically ‚Äúsizes over 35 ‚Äî thinking about The Row Margaux or the Birkin,‚Äù says Rivera. ‚ÄúNow that everybody‚Äôs coming back to the office, you want bags where you can fit your laptop and all your needs.‚Äù The Phantom, she adds, is ‚Äúin a very unique position to thrive.‚Äù Sciacca agrees, noting that a big part of the Phantom‚Äôs appeal is its practicality. ‚ÄúYou feel like you can be playful with fashion, but it‚Äôs a serious bag at the same time,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWhen I first started working at The RealReal, I was surprised by how many color combinations there were‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs still personal style. You‚Äôre not just subscribing to a trend, in that sense.‚Äù¬† The Phantom ‚Äúis a piece that will last over the years,‚Äù says Hersan. Even as other styles came and went, it was never totally out of the picture: ‚ÄúI could never say that it wasn‚Äôt on-trend anymore.‚Äù It has that ‚Äúeffortless silhouette that we‚Äôre looking for today,‚Äù when ‚Äúwe want to invest in more timeless pieces than ever.‚Äù¬† Another thing they agree on: Now‚Äôs the time to buy ‚Äî and sell. ¬†‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the very simple economics of supply and demand. As demand goes up, we can increase resale prices‚Ä¶ As these things start to be gobbled up on the resale market, there‚Äôs going to be less and less [inventory], so people will pay more of a premium,‚Äù Sciacca says. ‚ÄúTo anyone who wants to buy it: Scoop it up now, because if you wait a couple weeks, you‚Äôre going to pay hundreds of dollars more for it.‚Äù Like what you see? title: The Best Summer Dresses For When It‚Äôs Too Hot To Wear Anything Else
description: When it‚Äôs sweltering out, the only thing more appealing than blasting the AC is slipping into an ultra-lightweight dress that barely skims the body. Whether it‚Äôs a floaty cotton dress that breathes easily, a poplin midi with cut-outs for added airflow, or a linen maxi made for getaways, these summer-ready silhouettes are what we‚Äôll be living in from now through Labor Day.This edit includes the most breathable summer dresses we could find ‚Äî many with open backs, strategic slits, or draped shapes that won‚Äôt cling, bunch, or stick to sweaty skin. We‚Äôve got all the trends covered, too: shift dresses that go from desk to drinks, tiered and flowy dresses made for triple-digit temps, picnic-ready gingham, bubble hems that bring volume without weight, and standout hues like butter yellow and tangerine. Consider this your guide to surviving the heat in style ‚Äî whether your summer plans include a sardine-girl stroll through the city, a fisherman-coded coastal escape, or a destination wedding abroad (hello, European aesthetic). Mini Dresses Short, swingy, and made to float away from the body, these minis are your best defense against summer‚Äôs stickiest days. But heat-proof doesn‚Äôt mean shapeless or void of detail ‚Äî our favorites include ruched accents, exaggerated babydoll silhouettes, and not-overly-clingy smocking. Midi Dresses Midi lengths strike the perfect balance between ease and polish ‚Äî ideal for office days, dinner plans, or anything in between. Refresh your assortment with of-the-moment silhouettes featuring halter necklines, milkmaid-esque puff sleeves, and beautifully embroidered handkerchief designs. Maxi Dresses Maxis may offer the most coverage, but the best ones still feel easy, airy, and perfectly cool on hot days. Reach for a cut-out design or open back for date night, a cotton shirt dress for a day full of shopping and lunch, or a printed option that feels just right for a summer wedding or dinner outing. title: This $35 LOFT Skirt Nails the Bandana Trend I Keep Seeing on TikTok
description: Image Source: PS Photography | Marisa Petrarca My earliest memories of LOFT date back to when it was still called Ann Taylor LOFT, when I'd tag along with my mom to help her pick out work outfits. It's been a minute since I've stepped foot in a store, but recently, my TikTok algorithm (which knows me frighteningly well) served up a few trending fashion picks from the brand's website. And honestly? LOFT is delivering. The pieces feel exactly like the aesthetic I'm reaching for these days: elevated but effortless, polished yet comfortable. Cue me immediately adding the exact items they fed me to my cart: the Deco Mini Wrap Skirt ($35, originally $70) and the Ribbed Square Neck Sweater Tank Top ($27, originally $55). About the LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt The LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt is available in both regular and petite sizes. You can find it in stores and online. It's made of 100 percent lyocell and is machine washable. It measures 17.5 inches in length and features a straight, relaxed shift fit. What I Like About the LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt What I like most about the LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt is how it blends two trends I keep seeing on Pinterest: bandana prints and sarong-style silhouettes. The fit feels polished yet playful, and with the right accessories, I can wear it just as easily for daytime plans as I can for a night out. It's also incredibly easy to style. Admittedly, I'm not the most adventurous dresser, so this skirt speaks to my minimalist heart - it looks chic with anything black and white (though by all means, go bold if that's your thing). I paired it with a classic LOFT tank I'll be wearing on repeat year-round, the Staud handbag I wear constantly, and a pair of strappy black heels. Lastly (and at the risk of sounding a little obsessed), I love that this skirt isn't an online exclusive. So many pieces sell out fast online and are nearly impossible to track down. Thankfully, it's also available in stores, and I noticed that several Minnesota locations near me still had it in stock. (Can't promise the same for you, but I'm hopeful!) Image Source: PS Photography | Marisa Petrarca What to Consider About the LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt Something to keep in mind about the LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt is that it's made of 100 percent lyocell, which the brand lists as machine washable in the product details. While that's true, I did a little digging and found that the best way to keep it looking its best long-term is to wash it on a delicate cycle in cold water with a mild detergent, then air dry. I'm admittedly reaching for cons here, but if you're planning to keep this piece in regular rotation, it's worth noting. Where Is the LOFT Deco Mini Wrap Skirt Available? No shocker here: the Deco Mini Wrap Skirt is a LOFT exclusive, available both in stores and online. Marisa Petrarca (she/her) is a contributing editor for PS Shopping and has over seven years of experience writing and editing beauty, fashion, and lifestyle content. She was previously the senior beauty editor at Grazia USA and the style and beauty editor at Us Weekly. Now freelancing, her work has been featured in Cosmopolitan, Allure, Marie Claire, and more.

title: Amaya Espinal's Muumuu Is More Than Just a Viral "Love Island USA" Moment
description: It's no secret that "Love Island USA" is impacting current culture as we know it. While it's far from the first love-centered reality show that we've seen, its popularity is especially referential. The show's foundational concept is unusual alone - being secluded on an island away from the outside world to find the love you've been looking for all your life. Islanders also played a significant role in season seven's massive impact, including Olandria Carthen and Nicolas Vansteenberghe's kiss that caused a massive crash-out at "Love Island" watch parties. Another highlight from the show that's still on our minds? Amaya Espinal (aka our sensitive gangster) wearing a muumuu in episode 28. While the New Yorker's bubbly personality and witty candor have given us plenty of meme-worthy moments to reflect on, her muumuu is far from just another piece of clothing that's passed the TikTok viral test. In an interview with the Today show, Espinal revealed that she only had a day to prepare for the show before being flown to Fiji, so she threw a bunch of clothing in a suitcase - including the muumuu she got during a trip to Portugal. "Bringing that piece back to the villa reminded me of my travels and reminded me of the good days whenever I was having a bad one," she says. "It was more than a dress for sure - it really made me feel grounded." @dontask724 just a girl and her moo moo against the world #amaya #amayaloveisland #amayapapaya #loveislandusa #loveisland #usa #fyp #viral ‚ô¨ original sound - ìáº Apart from the sentimental value it holds for Espinal, the muumuu bears cultural significance that's particularly noteworthy. The comfortable piece can be traced back to the early 19th century, when Christian missionaries in Hawaii influenced native women to wear the silhouette to further cultivate modesty. Hawaiian women adapted a more casual, sleeveless version - the "holok≈´" - for everyday wear, before it was renamed the muumuu. Fast forward to present day, the dress style is still acceptable in Western culture, and often a go-to purchase for vacations, Hawaiian-themed parties like luaus, and more. And of course, celebrities have proudly embraced the muumuu - most recently, Kris Jenner, Oprah Winfrey, and Gayle King were seen wearing them on a Mallorca getaway. Espinal wearing her own speaks to the diversity we need to see more of on reality shows, and is a surefire way to exhibit the fact that modesty is still attractive. During the scene in which she wore it, her partner, Bryan Arenales, complimented her look (despite her labeling it as a "grandma dress"). His support proves that you don't always need to show skin to be deemed attractive or desired - especially in the eyes of your romantic partner. While her exact dress isn't available to shop, we found similar picks that evoke the same level of style and confidence: Unique Kaftans Floral Print Long Tunic Dress ($3, originally $10), JaipurCraftandArt Cotton Kaftan ($27, originally $75), and H&M Oversized Kaftan Dress ($75). Naomi Parris is an assistant shopping editor at Popsugar, based in New York. With over eight years of experience and previous roles held on the brand's Beauty and Operations teams, she enjoys telling stories that merge fashion, beauty, and Black culture. Naomi has also lent her skillful pen to Essence Girls United, Elle, Bustle, and Elite Daily. When she's not crafting shopping roundups, high-profile features, beauty op-eds, or trend guides, you can find Naomi behind her blog "Eli-Nay," where she inspires readers through style guides, cultural pieces, and innovative content on her Instagram.
